request.description:
## Auth0: Get Access Token

This request retrieves an OAuth 2.0 access token from Auth0 using the Client Credentials grant.

### Endpoint
- URL: `{{AUTH0_URL}}`
- Method: POST

Ensure the following variables are set in your active environment before sending the request:
- `{{AUTH0_URL}}`: Your Auth0 token endpoint, typically `https://YOUR_DOMAIN/oauth/token`
- `{{CLIENT_ID}}`: Auth0 application Client ID
- `{{CLIENT_SECRET}}`: Auth0 application Client Secret (store securely)
- `{{AUDIENCE}}`: Identifier of the API you want tokens for, e.g. `https://api.example.com/`
- `{{GRANT_TYPE}}`: For client credentials, use `client_credentials`

### Headers
- Content-Type: `application/json`

### Request Body (raw JSON)
```json
{
  "client_id": "{{CLIENT_ID}}",
  "client_secret": "{{CLIENT_SECRET}}",
  "audience": "{{AUDIENCE}}",
  "grant_type": "{{GRANT_TYPE}}"
}
```

### Successful Response
A successful request returns HTTP 200 with a JSON body like:
```json
{
  "access_token": "eyJ...",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 86400
}
```

### Post-response behavior
This request includes a test script that parses the JSON response and saves `access_token` to the current environment as `access_token`. You can reference it in subsequent requests via `{{access_token}}` (e.g., Authorization header: `Bearer {{access_token}}`).

### Notes
- Make sure the Audience matches an Auth0 API configured in your tenant.
- Keep CLIENT_SECRET in a secure variable store (Environment/Vault).
- If you receive 401/403 errors on downstream calls, verify audience and token scope.

console.log('titleId saved to TitlesId and titleId.');

request.description:
## createMysqlTitle

Creates a new title record in MySQL via GraphQL. This mutation returns either validation/operation errors or the created title object.

### Endpoint

- URL: `{{HOST}}`
    
- Protocol: GraphQL over HTTP (POST)
    

### Authentication

- If your server requires auth, set an appropriate Authorization header (e.g., Bearer {{access_token}}) using an environment variable.
    

### Variables

- `{{HOST}}`: Base GraphQL endpoint for your backend.
    
- `{{access_token}}` (optional): Bearer token if required by your API.
    

### Mutation

``` graphql
mutation CreateMysqlTitle {
  createMysqlTitle(
    input: {
      title: {
        titleType: "movie"
        primaryTitle: "The Movie"
        originalTitle: "The Movie"
        isAdult: true
        startYear: 2025
        endYear: null
        runtimeMinutes: 50
      }
    }
  ) {
    errors {
      ... on ArgumentError {
        message
        paramName
      }
      ... on InvalidOperationError {
        message
      }
    }
    titles {
      titleId
      titleType
      primaryTitle
      originalTitle
      isAdult
      startYear
      endYear
      runtimeMinutes
    }
  }
}

 ```

### Request Body (GraphQL)

- Operation type: `mutation`
    
- Operation name: `CreateMysqlTitle`
    
- Variables: none (empty)
    

### Input Fields

- `title.titleType` (string): e.g., `"movie"`.
    
- `title.primaryTitle` (string): Human-readable title.
    
- `title.originalTitle` (string): Original/primary language title.
    
- `title.isAdult` (boolean): If the title is adult content.
    
- `title.startYear` (number): Release year.
    
- `title.endYear` (number|null): End year if applicable; `null` for ongoing or single release.
    
- `title.runtimeMinutes` (number): Duration in minutes.
    

### Successful Response

On success, the `titles` field contains the created record.

``` json
{
  "data": {
    "createMysqlTitle": {
      "errors": [],
      "titles": {
        "titleId": 123,
        "titleType": "movie",
        "primaryTitle": "The Movie",
        "originalTitle": "The Movie",
        "isAdult": true,
        "startYear": 2025,
        "endYear": null,
        "runtimeMinutes": 50
      }
    }
  }
}

 ```

### Error Handling

- `errors.ArgumentError`: Input validation issues (e.g., missing/invalid fields).
    
- `errors.InvalidOperationError`: Operation-level errors.
    

### Test/Chaining Note

This request includes a test script that extracts `data.createMysqlTitle.titles.titleId` and saves it to the environment variable `titleId` for use in subsequent requests.

### Usage Tips

- Ensure `{{HOST}}` points to your GraphQL endpoint (e.g., `https://your-domain.com/graphql`).
    
- Associate an environment (e.g., Backend) and set `HOST` there.
    
- If authentication is enforced, set `access_token` in the environment and configure Authorization accordingly.

### Summary

Retrieves a MySQL title by its ID using a GraphQL query. This request queries the `mysqlTitles` field and returns a single item (if found) matching the provided `titleId`.

### Endpoint

- URL: `{{HOST}}`
    
- Protocol: GraphQL over HTTP (POST)
    

### Variables

- `{{HOST}}` (required): Base URL for the GraphQL server (for example: `https://your-server.com/graphql`).
    
- `{{titleId}}` (required): The title identifier to filter on.
    
- `{{access_token}}` (optional): If your server requires authentication, supply this via a Bearer token in the Authorization header at the request level or through an environment.
    

### GraphQL Query

```
query MysqlTitle {
  mysqlTitles(where: { titleId: { eq: "{{titleId}}" } }) {
    items {
      titleId
      titleType
      primaryTitle
      originalTitle
      isAdult
      startYear
      endYear
      runtimeMinutes
    }
  }
}

 ```

### Expected Response

- 200 OK with `data.mysqlTitles.items` as an array. If no item matches, the array may be empty.
    
- On auth errors, you may receive 401/403 responses depending on server configuration.
    

### Setup

1. Select an environment that defines `HOST` and `titleId`.
    
2. If authentication is required, add an Authorization header or configure the Authorization tab to use a Bearer token (e.g., `{{access_token}}`).
    

### Notes

- This request does not include pre-request or test scripts.
    
- No saved examples are present yet. Consider adding saved responses to improve documentation and enable mock servers.
